systemMessage.content:
# Game Developer AI Assistant (Windows + Repo-Scoped)

You are an expert game developer specializing in **frontend-only React + TypeScript** single-page browser games (no backend). You produce clean architecture, reliable tests, and thorough documentation.

## Operating Rules (Critical)

### Repo Scope (No External Files)

* **All files must be created/edited inside the current repository folder (the “Game Plan repo”).**
* **Never** read/write from `$HOME$/.copilot/sessions` or any other external session folder.
* **Never** store temp files outside the repo. If you need scratch space, use:

  * `.\.tmp\` (create if missing)
* All paths must be **relative to the repo root** unless explicitly required.

### Primary Plan of Record

* The canonical plan is: **`docs/plan.md`**
* Every dev session must:

  1. Read `docs/plan.md`
  2. Execute the next incomplete tasks
  3. Update checkboxes and progress notes in `docs/plan.md`
  4. Commit atomic changes

## Windows Tooling (Commands You May Use)

### Navigation & Inspection

* `cd`, `dir`, `tree`
* `type`, `more`
* `findstr` (search within files)

### File & Folder Management (Repo-only)

* `mkdir`, `rmdir /s /q`
* `del`
* `copy`, `xcopy`, `robocopy`
* `move`
* PowerShell equivalents allowed:

  * `Get-ChildItem`, `Get-Content`, `Set-Content`, `New-Item`, `Remove-Item`, `Copy-Item`, `Move-Item`

### Git / GitHub

* `git status`, `git diff`, `git add`, `git commit`, `git checkout -b`, `git push`
* `gh repo create`, `gh repo clone`
* `gh issue create`, `gh issue list`
* `gh pr create`, `gh pr merge`
* `gh release create`

### Node / React

* `npm install`, `npm run build`, `npm test`, `npm start`
* `npx` allowed when needed (prefer repo-local devDependencies)

## Architecture Principles

* **Frontend-only**: no server-side code, no external databases.
* Use browser APIs and `localStorage` for persistence.
* Use **React functional components + hooks**.
* Keep components small; isolate game logic in `src/utils/`.
* Prefer minimal dependencies; justify anything new.

## Standard Project Structure

```
/
├── .github/
│   └── copilot-instructions.md
├── docs/
│   └── plan.md
├── src/
│   ├── components/
│   ├── hooks/
│   ├── utils/
│   └── App.tsx
├── tests/
├── README.md
└── package.json
```

## Test & Quality Requirements

* Write tests for core game logic (rules, scoring, collisions, state transitions).
* **Run tests before every commit**: `npm test`
* Fix failing tests immediately.
* Keep changes small and reviewable.

## Documentation Requirements

### README.md Must Include

* Game description + how to play
* How to run locally:

  * `npm install`
  * `npm start`
* Controls
* Feature list
* Tech stack

### docs/plan.md Rules

* Use phases and checkbox tasks:

  * `- [ ] Task`
  * `- [x] Task`
* Update after every session:

  * mark completed tasks
  * add brief notes on deviations or decisions

## “Execute the Plan” Session Loop (docs/plan.md)


Create a feature branch: `featurex`

For each session, follow this exact loop:

1. **Confirm repo root**

   * Ensure commands run from the repo root (where `package.json` exists).
   * 
2. **Read plan**

   * Open `docs/plan.md` and identify the next `- [ ]` tasks.
  
3. **Implement**

   * Make changes only inside the repo.
4. **Test**

   * Run `npm test` (and `npm run build` if appropriate).
5. **Commit**

   * Atomic commit with a clear message:

     * `feat: ...`, `fix: ...`, `test: ...`, `docs: ...`, `refactor: ...`
6. **Update plan**

   * Check off completed tasks and add a short progress note.
7. **Repeat**

   * Continue until the planned session scope is complete.

When completed make sure you 

1. push the committed changes to the current feature branch 

2. Create a pull request to merge the current branch into main

3. send communication saying a Pull Request has been created. The puul request will need to be completed by hand

## New Game Creation (Windows Location)

When starting a new game repo:

1. Create the folder: `C:\development\repos\<github-repo-name>`
2. Create a new repo at https://github.com/philiv99/<github-repo-name>
4. **IMPORTANT: make sure it has a README.md and an appropriate .gitignore File**
5. add all files to commit
6. create main branch 
7. push commits to main branch
8. Create `docs/plan.md` and `.github/copilot-instructions.md`
9. Begin execution using the session loop above

## Non-Negotiables

* No backend services. No server APIs. No databases.
* No file operations outside the repo folder.
* No `$HOME$/.copilot/sessions`.
* `docs/plan.md` is the single source of truth for what to do next.

messages.content:
# SeekingTheWord — Word Search Game (React Web App) Requirements

## 1. Project Overview

**SeekingTheWord** is a browser-based word search game built as a **React web application**. The game generates a **10 × 10** grid of letters containing **exactly 5 hidden words** placed in random positions and directions. Players find words by **clicking and dragging across the grid** to select a continuous sequence of letters. When a correct word is found, the game visually confirms it and tracks progress until all 5 words are found.

---

## 2. Core Gameplay Requirements

### 2.1 Game Objective

* The user must find **all hidden words** embedded in the grid.
* The hidden words must **NOT** be shown anywhere in the UI until the player successfully finds them.

### 2.2 Player Interaction Model

* The player selects letters by:

  1. **Mouse Down** on a grid cell
  2. **Mouse Drag** across adjacent cells
  3. **Mouse Up** to finalize the selection

* On mouse up:

  * The system evaluates the selected letters as a candidate word.
  * If the candidate word matches one of the hidden words, it is considered “found.”

---

## 3. Grid Rules and Word Placement

### 3.1 Grid Size

* The letter grid must always be **10 rows × 10 columns**.

### 3.2 Hidden Word Count

* The grid must contain **exactly 10 hidden words**.

### 3.3 Word Placement Directions

Each hidden word may be placed in the grid using any of the following directions:

* Horizontal:
  * Left → Right
  * Right → Left (backwards)
* Vertical:
  * Top → Bottom
  * Bottom → Top (backwards)
* Diagonal:
  * Top-left → Bottom-right
  * Bottom-right → Top-left (backwards)
  * Top-right → Bottom-left
  * Bottom-left → Top-right (backwards)
* Zig Zag:
   * any combination of the above directions


### 3.4 Word Placement Constraints

The word generator must enforce all of the following:

1. **Words may be forward or backward.**
2. **Words may be placed anywhere in the grid** as long as they fit fully within bounds.
3. **No shared letters between words**
   * No grid cell may belong to more than one hidden word.
4. **Every word must be fully placeable**

   * If a generated word list cannot be placed under these constraints, the generator must retry with a new layout.

### 3.5 Non-Word Letters

* All remaining empty cells not occupied by words must be filled with random letters (A–Z).

---

## 4. Word Detection and Validation

### 4.1 What Counts as a Valid Find

A selection counts as a valid found word if:

* The selected letters form **exactly one** of the hidden words
* The word has **not already been found**
* Matching must support:

  * Forward and backward (e.g., selecting “DOG” or “GOD” should count if “DOG” is hidden backwards)

### 4.2 Invalid Selections

If the player releases the mouse and the selected letters do not match a remaining hidden word:

* No word is marked found
* The selection highlight (if any temporary highlighting exists) is cleared

---

## 5. Visual Feedback and UI Behavior

### 5.1 Default Grid Display

* The grid is displayed as a clean 10×10 board of letters.
* Letters are visible at all times.

### 5.2 Selection Feedback (While Dragging)

During drag-selection:

* The current selection path must be visibly highlighted so the user can see what they are selecting in real time.

### 5.3 Feedback When a Word is Found

When a word is successfully found:

1. **Celebrate immediately**

   * Trigger a short animated “Congratulations!” effect (lightweight and non-blocking)
2. **Lock the word visually**

   * The letters belonging to the found word must remain highlighted permanently for the rest of the game
3. **Add the word to the Found Words list**

   * A “Found Words” area appears under the grid.
   * Only found words are listed.
   * The hidden word list must never be shown ahead of time.

---

## 6. Win Condition and Endgame Behavior

### 6.1 Game Completion Rule

* The game is won when **all 5 words are found**.

### 6.2 Final Winning Celebration Modal

When the final (5th) word is found:

* Display a **happy animated modal** congratulating the player.
* Modal requirements:

  * Clearly communicates game completion (e.g., “You found them all!”)
  * Has visible animation (e.g., bounce, confetti, sparkle, etc.)
  * Must be dismissible by **clicking anywhere on the UI**
  * Should overlay the grid and rest of the UI while visible

### 6.3 Input Lock When Game Ends

After winning:

* The grid must remain visible
* The application must **ignore all mouse input on the grid**

  * No additional selecting, dragging, or word checks

---

## 7. Restarting and Replay Behavior

### 7.1 Play Again Button

After the game ends, the UI must provide a **“Play Again”** button.

When clicked:

* The game restarts from scratch with:

  * A **new set of 10 hidden words**
  * A **new generated 10×10 grid**
  * Found word list cleared
  * Input enabled again

### 7.2 Modal Dismissal Auto-Restart Behavior

When the player clicks anywhere to dismiss the final winning modal:

* The modal closes
* The application must immediately:

  * Generate a brand-new game (new hidden words + new grid)
  * Restart gameplay automatically
  * Enable input again
  * Ensure no prior game state remains

**Important:** This auto-restart behavior occurs specifically when dismissing the final modal.

---

## 8. State Management Requirements (Functional Expectations)

The app must track at minimum:

* Current generated 10×10 grid letters
* The 5 hidden words used in the current game (internal only; not shown to user)
* Coordinates/paths for each hidden word placement (for highlighting found letters)
* Current drag selection path (temporary)
* Set/list of found words
* Game status flags:

  * `isSelecting` (dragging active)
  * `gameOver` (input locked after win)
  * `showWinModal` (final modal visibility)

---

## 9. Non-Functional Requirements

### 9.1 Responsiveness / Layout

* Must display correctly on common desktop browser sizes.
* Grid cells should be square and evenly spaced.
* UI must be readable and visually consistent.

### 9.2 Deterministic UX Rules

* A found word must not be re-added to the found list.
* The hidden word list must never appear until found.
* Once the game is won, input must remain disabled until a restart occurs.

---

## 10. Deliverable Summary

The final deliverable is a complete React web application that:

1. Generates a 10×10 word search grid
2. Hides 10 words placed in any direction (including backwards)
3. Prevents words from overlapping or sharing grid letters
4. Supports click-and-drag selection
5. Detects valid found words on mouse up
6. Highlights found words permanently and lists them under the grid
7. Shows an animated final win modal when all 5 are found
8. Prevents further input after win
9. Supports restarting via **Play Again**
10. Also restarts automatically when the final win modal is dismissed

{"path":"C:\development\repos\SeekingTheWord\README.md","file_text":"# SeekingTheWord 🔍

A fun, browser-based word search puzzle game built with React and TypeScript.

## 🎮 Game Description

**SeekingTheWord** challenges players to find 10 hidden words in a 10×10 letter grid. Words can be placed horizontally, vertically, diagonally, or even in zig-zag patterns - forwards or backwards!

## 🎯 How to Play

1. Look at the 10×10 grid of letters
2. **Click and drag** across letters to select a word
3. If your selection matches a hidden word, it's marked as found!
4. Find all 10 words to win the game
5. Click anywhere or press "Play Again" to start a new game

## 🚀 Getting Started

### Prerequisites

- Node.js (v18 or higher)
- npm (v9 or higher)

### Installation

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/philiv99/SeekingTheWord.git

# Navigate to the project directory
cd SeekingTheWord

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start the development server
npm start
```

The game will open in your browser at `http://localhost:3000`.

## 🎮 Controls

| Action | Input |
|--------|-------|
| Start selection | Click on a letter |
| Continue selection | Drag across adjacent letters |
| Submit selection | Release mouse button |
| New game | Click "Play Again" button |

## ✨ Features

- **10×10 dynamic grid** with randomly placed words
- **Multiple word directions**: horizontal, vertical, diagonal, and zig-zag
- **Forward and backward** word placement
- **Click-and-drag** word selection
- **Visual highlighting** of found words
- **Animated celebrations** when finding words
- **Victory modal** with confetti when all words are found
- **Instant replay** - start a new game anytime

## 🛠️ Tech Stack

- **React 18** - UI framework
- **TypeScript** - Type safety
- **CSS3** - Styling and animations
- **LocalStorage** - Game state persistence (optional)

## 📁 Project Structure

```
SeekingTheWord/
├── src/
│   ├── components/     # React components
│   ├── hooks/          # Custom React hooks
│   ├── utils/          # Game logic utilities
│   ├── types/          # TypeScript type definitions
│   ├── App.tsx         # Main app component
│   └── index.tsx       # Entry point
├── tests/              # Test files
├── docs/               # Documentation
└── public/             # Static assets
```

## 📄 License

MIT License - feel free to use and modify!

---

**Have fun seeking the words! 🎉**
"}

{"file_text":"# SeekingTheWord - Development Plan

## Project Overview
A browser-based word search game built with React and TypeScript. Players find 10 hidden words in a 10×10 grid by clicking and dragging to select letters.

---

## Phase 1: Project Setup ✅
- [x] Create GitHub repository
- [x] Initialize with README.md and .gitignore
- [x] Create React app with TypeScript
- [x] Set up project structure
- [x] Push initial setup to main branch

---

## Phase 2: Core Game Logic
- [ ] Create TypeScript types/interfaces for game state
- [ ] Implement word list manager (curated word bank)
- [ ] Implement grid generation algorithm
  - [ ] Word placement in all 8 directions
  - [ ] Zig-zag word placement support
  - [ ] No overlap validation
  - [ ] Random letter fill for empty cells
- [ ] Implement word selection validation
- [ ] Write unit tests for grid generation
- [ ] Write unit tests for word validation

---

## Phase 3: UI Components
- [ ] Create Grid component (10×10 letter display)
- [ ] Create Cell component (individual letter)
- [ ] Implement click-and-drag selection
  - [ ] Mouse down handler
  - [ ] Mouse move/drag handler
  - [ ] Mouse up handler
- [ ] Visual highlighting during selection
- [ ] Permanent highlighting for found words
- [ ] Create FoundWords component (list of found words)
- [ ] Style components with CSS

---

## Phase 4: Game State Management
- [ ] Implement useGameState custom hook
- [ ] Track current grid state
- [ ] Track hidden words (internal)
- [ ] Track found words
- [ ] Track selection state
- [ ] Track game over state
- [ ] Implement game reset logic

---

## Phase 5: Win Condition & Celebrations
- [ ] Implement word-found celebration animation
- [ ] Create WinModal component
- [ ] Implement confetti/sparkle animation
- [ ] Add modal dismiss handler
- [ ] Implement auto-restart on modal dismiss
- [ ] Add "Play Again" button
- [ ] Lock input after game win

---

## Phase 6: Polish & Testing
- [ ] Responsive design adjustments
- [ ] Accessibility improvements
- [ ] Performance optimization
- [ ] Final integration testing
- [ ] Cross-browser testing
- [ ] Update documentation

---

## Progress Notes

### Session 1 - Initial Setup
- Created repository structure
- Set up React with TypeScript
- Created initial documentation

---

## Technical Decisions

### Word Placement Algorithm
- Use backtracking algorithm for reliable placement
- Support all 8 directional vectors + zig-zag patterns
- Validate no cell overlap before committing placement

### State Management
- Use React hooks (useState, useReducer)
- No external state library needed for this scope

### Styling Approach
- CSS modules or plain CSS
- CSS animations for celebrations
- Grid layout for the board

{"file_text":"# Copilot Instructions for SeekingTheWord

## Project Context
SeekingTheWord is a browser-based word search puzzle game built with React and TypeScript. It is a frontend-only application with no backend services.

## Architecture Guidelines

### Tech Stack
- React 18 with functional components and hooks
- TypeScript for type safety
- CSS for styling (no CSS-in-JS libraries)
- Jest for testing

### Project Structure
```
src/
├── components/    # React UI components
├── hooks/         # Custom React hooks
├── utils/         # Pure utility functions (game logic)
├── types/         # TypeScript interfaces and types
├── App.tsx        # Main application component
└── index.tsx      # Entry point
```

### Code Style
- Use functional components with hooks
- Keep components small and focused
- Extract game logic into utility functions
- Use TypeScript interfaces for all data structures
- Write tests for utility functions

## Game-Specific Context

### Grid System
- 10×10 letter grid
- Coordinates as {row, col} objects
- Direction vectors for word placement

### Word Placement Rules
- 8 standard directions + zig-zag patterns
- No overlapping words allowed
- Words can be forward or backward

### Selection System
- Click and drag to select
- Validate on mouse up
- Support both forward and backward matching

## Testing Requirements
- Unit tests for grid generation
- Unit tests for word validation
- Test word placement constraints

## Documentation
- Update docs/plan.md after each session
- Keep README.md current with features

A fun, browser-based word search puzzle game built with React and TypeScript.

## 🎮 Game Description

**SeekingTheWord** challenges players to find 10 hidden words in a 10×10 letter grid. Words can be placed horizontally, vertically, diagonally, or even in zig-zag patterns - forwards or backwards!

## 🎯 How to Play

1. Look at the 10×10 grid of letters
2. **Click and drag** across letters to select a word
3. If your selection matches a hidden word, it's marked as found!
4. Find all 10 words to win the game
5. Click anywhere or press "Play Again" to start a new game

## 🚀 Getting Started

### Prerequisites

- Node.js (v18 or higher)
- npm (v9 or higher)

### Installation

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/philiv99/seekingtheword.git

# Navigate to the project directory
cd seekingtheword

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start the development server
npm start
```

The game will open in your browser at `http://localhost:3000`.

## 🎮 Controls

| Action | Input |
|--------|-------|
| Start selection | Click on a letter |
| Continue selection | Drag across adjacent letters |
| Submit selection | Release mouse button |
| New game | Click "Play Again" button |

## ✨ Features

- **10×10 dynamic grid** with randomly placed words
- **Multiple word directions**: horizontal, vertical, diagonal, and zig-zag
- **Forward and backward** word placement
- **Click-and-drag** word selection
- **Visual highlighting** of found words
- **Animated celebrations** when finding words
- **Victory modal** with confetti when all words are found
- **Instant replay** - start a new game anytime

## 🛠️ Tech Stack

- **React 18** - UI framework
- **TypeScript** - Type safety
- **CSS3** - Styling and animations

## 📁 Project Structure

```
seekingtheword/
├── src/
│   ├── components/     # React components
│   ├── hooks/          # Custom React hooks
│   ├── utils/          # Game logic utilities
│   ├── types/          # TypeScript type definitions
│   ├── App.tsx         # Main app component
│   └── index.tsx       # Entry point
├── docs/               # Documentation
└── public/             # Static assets
```

## Available Scripts

### `npm start`

Runs the app in development mode at [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000).

### `npm test`

Launches the test runner in interactive watch mode.

### `npm run build`

Builds the app for production to the `build` folder.

## 📄 License

MIT License - feel free to use and modify!

---

**Have fun seeking the words! 🎉**"}

## Project Overview
A browser-based word search game built with React and TypeScript. Players find 10 hidden words in a 10×10 grid by clicking and dragging to select letters.

  - [ ] Word placement in all 8 directions

  - [ ] Random letter fill for empty cells
- [ ] Implement word selection validation

- [ ] Track found words

## Phase 5: Win Condition & Celebrations

## Phase 6: Polish & Testing
- [ ] Responsive design adjustments
- [ ] Accessibility improvements
- [ ] Performance optimization
- [ ] Final integration testing
- [ ] Cross-browser testing
- [ ] Update documentation

### Session 1 - Initial Setup (2026-01-24)
- Created repository structure
- Set up React with TypeScript using create-react-app

---

## Technical Decisions

### Word Placement Algorithm
- Use backtracking algorithm for reliable placement
- Support all 8 directional vectors + zig-zag patterns

### State Management
- Use React hooks (useState, useReducer)
- No external state library needed for this scope

### Styling Approach
- CSS modules or plain CSS
- CSS animations for celebrations
- Grid layout for the board

{"file_text":"# Copilot Instructions for SeekingTheWord

## Project Context
SeekingTheWord is a browser-based word search puzzle game built with React and TypeScript. It is a frontend-only application with no backend services.

## Architecture Guidelines

### Tech Stack
- React 18 with functional components and hooks
- TypeScript for type safety
- CSS for styling (no CSS-in-JS libraries)
- Jest for testing

### Project Structure
```
src/
├── components/    # React UI components
├── hooks/         # Custom React hooks
├── utils/         # Pure utility functions (game logic)
├── types/         # TypeScript interfaces and types
├── App.tsx        # Main application component
└── index.tsx      # Entry point
```

### Code Style
- Use functional components with hooks
- Keep components small and focused
- Extract game logic into utility functions
- Use TypeScript interfaces for all data structures
- Write tests for utility functions

## Game-Specific Context

### Grid System
- 10×10 letter grid
- Coordinates as {row, col} objects
- Direction vectors for word placement

### Word Placement Rules
- 8 standard directions + zig-zag patterns
- No overlapping words allowed
- Words can be forward or backward

### Selection System
- Click and drag to select
- Validate on mouse up
- Support both forward and backward matching

## Testing Requirements
- Unit tests for grid generation
- Unit tests for word validation
- Test word placement constraints

## Documentation
- Update docs/plan.md after each session
- Keep README.md current with features

## 🎮 SeekingTheWord is Running!

The game is now live and ready to play:

### 🌐 URL to Play

**http://localhost:3001**

(Port 3000 was in use, so it started on port 3001)

---

### How to Play
1. Open **http://localhost:3001** in your browser
2. Look at the 10×10 grid of letters
3. **Click and drag** across letters to select a word
4. If your selection matches a hidden word, it lights up with a celebration!
5. Find all **10 hidden words** to win
6. Click anywhere on the victory modal or press "Play Again" to start a new game

### Controls
| Action | Input |
|--------|-------|
| Start selection | Click on a letter |
| Continue selection | Drag across adjacent letters |
| Submit selection | Release mouse button |
| New game | Click "Play Again" button |

The development server is running in the background. Enjoy the game! 🔍✨
now shutdown the game

## ✅ "I Give Up" Feature Added!

The game is running at **http://localhost:3001**

### New Feature: "I Give Up" Button 🏳️

When you click the **"I Give Up"** button:

1. **Found words** - Keep their original colorful highlighting (gold, coral, teal, etc.)
2. **Unfound words** - Are revealed with **black background and white text**
3. The game ends and the **"Play Again"** button appears

### Visual Summary

| Word Status | Background | Text Color |
|-------------|-----------|------------|
| Found by user | Colorful (10 unique colors) | Dark |
| Unfound (give up) | **Black** | **White** |
| Not part of any word | White | Dark |

### Changes Made

- Added `giveUp` handler in `useGameState` hook
- Added `gaveUp` state tracking
- New `isUnfound` prop on Cell component
- Red gradient "I Give Up" button styling
- Reveal animation for unfound word cells

The PR at https://github.com/philiv99/seekingtheword/pull/1 has been updated with this new commit.

Please update this to I Give Up behavior. I want the display of the unfound words to reveal them distinctly, to display the words with some kind of distinct styling that allows the user to see each word and what the order of the spelling is.

messages.content:
## ✅ "I Give Up" Feature Enhanced!

The game is running at **http://localhost:3001**

### New "I Give Up" Display Features

When you click **"I Give Up"**, unfound words are now displayed distinctly:

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Unique Colors** | Each unfound word has its own dark color (dark red, dark green, dark blue, etc.) |
| **Letter Numbers** | Small numbers (1, 2, 3...) in the corner of each cell show the spelling order |
| **First Letter Highlight** | The first letter of each word has a bright white border and glow effect |
| **Word Legend** | A new panel shows all missed words with matching colors |
| **Animated Reveal** | Words animate in with a pop effect |

### Visual Example

```
┌───┬───┬───┬───┐
│ C │ A │ T │   │  ← Unfound word "CAT" in dark red
│ 1 │ 2 │ 3 │   │     with numbers showing order
└───┴───┴───┴───┘
  ↑
First letter has
white glowing border
```

### Color Scheme

- **Found words**: Bright celebratory colors (gold, coral, teal, etc.)
- **Unfound words**: Darker distinct colors (dark red, dark green, dark blue, etc.) with white text

The PR at https://github.com/philiv99/seekingtheword/pull/1 has been updated.

two modifications. First in the layout. I want the display to show on the left the words that have been attempted but are not hidden words. I want the found words to show in a list on the right side of the screen. I want the information about how many words out of all words 1 of 10, for example, to show at the above the grid with the I give up button to the right of this display at the top. Also, the style of the first letter of the unfound words (showing after I give up) should be not glowing white, but glowing red.

## ✅ Layout Redesign Complete!

The game is still running at **http://localhost:3001** - refresh to see the changes.

### New Layout

```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                   🔍 SeekingTheWord                         │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│         Found: 3 of 10          [🏳️ I Give Up]             │
├─────────────────┬─────────────────────┬─────────────────────┤
│  ❌ Failed      │                     │  ✅ Found Words     │
│  Attempts       │    [GAME GRID]      │                     │
│                 │                     │    APPLE            │
│  XYZAB         │    10 x 10          │    BEACH            │
│  QWERT         │                     │    CASTLE           │
│  ...           │                     │    ...              │
└─────────────────┴─────────────────────┴─────────────────────┘
```

### Changes Made

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Left Sidebar** | Shows failed attempts (words you tried that weren't hidden) |
| **Right Sidebar** | Shows found words |
| **Top Bar** | Progress "Found: X of 10" with "I Give Up" button to the right |
| **First Letter Glow** | Changed from white to **red** for unfound words |
| **Responsive** | Stacks vertically on smaller screens |

### Tracking Failed Attempts
- Any selection of 2+ letters that doesn't match a hidden word is tracked
- Displayed in the left sidebar with red styling
- Helps you remember what you've already tried
